captions.text:
If you get caught in the middle of a big,
open field during a lightning storm, which

of the following uniforms would be most likely
to keep you safe? A thick wetsuit; a superman

costume; a medieval coat of armor; or a birthday
suit?

If you answered "medieval coat of armor,"
you might be a little crazy--but you'd also

be right. You'd be crazy, of course, because
lightning is much more likely to strike metal

than to strike rubber, fabric, or bare skin.
The reason is that lightning bolts are just

long streams of fast-flowing electrons looking
for the easiest path from point A to point

B, and no everyday material provides an easier
path than metal.

So why would a material that lures lightning
bolts keep you safe during a thunderstorm?

Ironically, for the exact same reason it attracts
the the lightning in the first place: metal

is a great conductor of electricity. Electrons
glide so easily over metals that they barely

penetrate into the surface. And if an electrical
current happens to be moving over a hollow

metal container, like a can or a box or even
a welded coat of armor, the current won't
reach the inside of the container.

Physicists call this kind of container a Faraday
cage . Or, in the case of the steel-woven

clothing worn by linemen working on high-voltage
wires, a Faraday suit.  In fact, your car

is an everyday example of a Faraday cage,
which is why--despite what you may have heard

about rubber tires--it's actually the closed
metal body surrounding you that keeps you

safe. It channels lightning around, rather
than through you.

Of course, if you're away from your car and
get caught in an open field during a storm,

chances are slim that you'll have a medieval
coat of armor or high voltage line-suit handy.

In that case, whether you're naked or in costume,
your body unfortunately happens to be a better

electrical conductor than both air and soil,
so it provides a great shortcut for traveling

current. Stand upright, and you're the fastest
route for a descending lightning bolt. Lie

down, and you're the best path for current
racing along the ground from a nearby strike.

So the best thing to do is crouch low and
keep your feet close together. Crouching low

is obvious. But similarly important, when
your feet are right next to each other, your

legs don't make for much of a shortcut for
the current to get from A to B. And even if

they are the best path for the lightning,
when your feet are the only thing touching

the ground, then the current will most likely
travel up one leg and down the other, missing

critical organs like your heart--something
these cows couldn't avoid.

But, actually, the real best thing to do is
avoid lightning altogether--armor or no armor--and

head indoors when you spot a storm on the
horizon.

comments.text:
Lighting rods don't prevent lighting from striking an area, they just 
provide an alternate path for lightning to go through, that is safer and 
better for us humans. The lightning rod actually is more likely to be 
struck by lightning than it's surroundings, as the metal warps the electric 
field lines (created by the potential difference between the clouds and the 
ground) toward itself making lighting more likely to strike that point.
comments.author: shellsamurai

comments.text:
+Ranstead Moons For neutralizing charges on the large scale needed to 
prevent a strike, the electric field at the tip of a lighting rod (or even 
at the top of a high rise building) is not anywhere sufficient to have any 
useful effect.  

As a practical matter, a thunderstorm can charge the upper atmosphere at a 
much, much higher rate than all the available leakage paths can provide for 
discharge. That's why severe lightning storms still occur over large cities 
with a lot of high rise buildings.

In summary, the only way to prevent a lightning discharge is to leak off 
the charge between the cloud and the ground as fast as it's created.
comments.author: kansasthunderman1

comments.text:
+kansasthunderman1 It's not about the surface area of the rod, it's about 
the electric field strength at the tip of the rod. Sharp points have a very 
high field density and can ionize the air using nothing but the potential 
of earth to clouds. The whole point isn't to allow a "highly conductive 
path" to the clouds, because that my friend would be called "Lightning". 
The point is to ionize the air, ripping electrons from their positive ions, 
and repelling these positive ions into the clouds where they absorb 
electrons and neutralize charges.
Electrons don't just "Dissipate" through the air... well, they do.. but at 
such a tiny rate that it might as well be zero. Electrons only flow through 
air when they exceed the breakdown voltage. That breakdown voltage for air 
is about 3000V per mm, which is why lightning strikes carry so much energy. 
The lightning rod DOES reduce the chances of a strike occuring, but you are 
right in that if it fails to prevent a strike it does provide a shorter 
path to earth.
comments.author: Ranstead Moons

comments.text:
+Ranstead Moons Dissipation is based on the leakage current between two 
charged objects.

In the case of a thunderstorm, the cloud base is one electrode (positively 
charged) and the ground below it is another electrode that becomes 
negatively charged.

Because of the large surface area of the cloud and ground electrodes, the 
volume of the atmosphere between them act like resistors in connected in 
parallel along a vertical path. In addition to the vertical path, the 
resistive network can also have horizontal components so there are billions 
of three dimensional paths through the volume of the atmosphere.

In accordance with Ohm's Law, the resistance of the three dimensional paths 
is extremely low and a very large leakage current (electrons) can flow 
between the ground and the cloud.

The leakage current over a large area of the ground can dissipate some of 
the charge. However the problem with applying the dissipation theory to 
lightning rods is that the small area of the rods are miniscule compared 
with the total area of the ground. Therefore, leakage path through the rods 
themselves can not conduct enough electrons to equalize the rate of charge 
build up due to convection in the storm. 

Experiments with laser ionization of the atmosphere below a storm indicate 
that creating a few highly conductive leakage paths are also insufficient 
to prevent a lightning discharge. In all cases, the convection in a 
thunderstorm is so great that the charge between the cloud and the ground 
can build up much faster than it can be dissipated by leakage through any 
practical means.

Inevitably, the potential will reach a threshold sufficient to cause an 
avalanche of electrons and create a lightning discharge. The paths can also 
take a different share of the current and that's why a lightning discharge 
can have very erratic and spectacular shapes. 

In summary, experiments prove that lightning rods alone cannot provide a 
sufficient path to dissipate any significant amount of the charge in a 
thunderstorm and a lightning strike will be inevitable. The main objective 
of lightning rods is to provide a safe path for the high voltage and 
current around a vulnerable object.

It's quite a bit more complicated than that.
As an electromagnetic wave travels through anything it will transfer part 
of that electric power to heat power as it excites electrons. What you see 
in lightbulbs or heating coils. They glow because they heat up, from the 
electricity passing through them. Power lines use thick wires to reduce 
this heating, the thicker the wire, the more power you can push through it 
without heating it to the point of melting anything. Even though the power 
in the lines is on it's way to thousands of homes(or the ground) it still 
interferes with the metal during transmission.

If a material(Metal) is saturated with charge then the excess will jump to 
nearby objects that have less charge in them (Yourself if the suit has too 
much charge in it). The power will spread out. :)

I'll always remember how dumb I was as a kid, when it comes to lightning.
I was on a camping trip with my class and the 2nd evening it starts pouring 
down, with violent lightning strikes all around, but I tell my friends that 
it's okay; that all we had to do is keep jumping, not to touch the ground *(because...? 
it would totally cancel out the lightning if it struck us, while off the 
ground - I mean, it's not like a charge of energy that could travel all the 
way from the clouds to us, would have the energy to travel from our feet to 
the ground below, right? [sarcasm])* So, like a bunch of numb-nuts, we'd be 
out in this large field, looking up at the clouds, jumping up and down. Boy 
would my face be red to this day, if a friend of mine next to me, had taken 
a bolt to the face and wound up a charred lump of meat.﻿

lightning passing trough it.

comments.author: Wolfgang Alexander Moens

comments.text:
Links:

a. *MinuteEarth*: How to Survive a Lightning Strike

b. *Lightning Strike*: Lightning strikes can produce severe injuries, and 
have a mortality rate of between 10% and 30%, with up to 80% of survivors 
sustaining long-term injuries. These severe injuries are not usually caused 
by thermal burns, since the current is too brief to greatly heat up 
tissues[citation needed]; instead, nerves and muscles may be directly 
damaged by the high voltage producing holes in their cell membranes, a 
process called electroporation.

In a direct strike, the electrical currents in the flash channel pass 
directly through the victim. The relatively high voltage drop around poorer 
electrical conductors (such as a human being), causes the surrounding air 
to ionize and break down, and the external flashover diverts most of the 
main discharge current so that it passes "around" the body, reducing injury.

Metallic objects in contact with the skin may "concentrate" the lightning's 
energy, given it is a better natural conductor and the preferred pathway, 
resulting in more serious injuries, such as burns from molten or 
evaporating metal. At least two cases have been reported where a strike 
victim wearing an iPod suffered more serious injuries as a result.

However, during a flash, the transient stroke current flowing through the 
channel and around the body will generate large electromagnetic fields and 
EMPs, which may induce electrical transients (surges) within the nervous 
system or pacemaker of the heart, upsetting normal operations. This effect 
might explain the cases where cardiac arrest or seizures followed a 
lightning strike that produced no external injuries. It may also point to 
the victim not being directly struck at all, but being very close to the 
strike termination.

Another effect of lightning on bystanders is to their hearing. The 
resulting shock wave of thunder can damage the ears. Also, electrical 
interference to telephones or headphones may result in damaging acoustic 
noise. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lightning_strike
